if the friction and mass is given then yes  remember f=mu.N

friction points in the direction of acceleration so in some cases it points in the direction of movement and other times it points in the opposite direction. Think about if you were to go running, you use the friction between your shoes and the ground to start moving (friction pointing towards movement) and when you want to stop running you use less force on the ground to slow yourself down (friction moving in opposite direction from movement). hope this helps
I have the same question ☹️

You're trying to find the max speed before the car will skid in the radial direction. Keep in mind the wheels are rolling forward; the friction that keeps them from skidding (sliding across the road) is static. Remember that kinetic friction has to do with objects that are sliding. The wheels having rolling friction but that is in the forward direction.
@rrenshaw7797  brilliant dude 👏🏽👏🏽👏🏽
The friction is static until the car starts sliding.
mg isn't considered negative instead it is considered +ve
The tires on the car that make it move aren't sliding across the ground, but are turning. They use the friction of the tire against the road to push the car. hope this clears things up
